this.ask_question = function(){ return this.the_answer; }}var deep_thought = new BigComputer(42);var the_meaning = deep_thought.ask_question(); // 42 Êàë‰ª¨Ê≤°ÊúâÁõ¥Êé•ÂàõÂª∫Ëøô‰∏™deep_thoughtÂØπË±°ÔºåËÄåÊòØÂÜô‰∫Ü‰∏Ä‰∏™ÂáΩÊï∞ÂéªÂàõÂª∫BigComputerÂØπË±°ÔºåÂπ∂‰∏îÈÄöËøánewÂÖ≥ÈîÆÂ≠óÔºåÂÆû‰æãÂåñ‰∫Ü‰∏Ä‰∏™deep_thoughtÂÆû‰æãÂèòÈáè„ÄÇÂΩì new BigComputer()ÊâßË°åÁöÑÊó∂ÂÄôÔºåÂú®ÂêéÂè∞ÂÖ¨ÂºÄÂú∞ÂàõÂª∫‰∫Ü‰∏Ä‰∏™ÂÖ®Êñ∞ÁöÑÂØπË±°„ÄÇBigComputerË¢´Ë∞ÉÁî®‰∫ÜÔºåÂπ∂‰∏îÂÆÉÁöÑthisÂÖ≥ÈîÆÂ≠óË¢´ËÆæÁΩÆ‰∏∫ÂºïÁî®ÈÇ£‰∏™Êñ∞ÂØπË±°„ÄÇËøô‰∏™ÂáΩÊï∞ÂèØ‰ª•Âú®this‰∏äËÆæÁΩÆÂ±ûÊÄßÂíåÊñπÊ≥ïÔºåÂú®BigComputerÊâßË°åÁªìÊùüÊó∂ÂÖ¨ÂºÄÂú∞ËøîÂõû„ÄÇ ‰ΩÜÊòØËØ∑Ê≥®ÊÑèÔºådeep_thought.the_question()‰ªçÁÑ∂ÂÉè‰ª•Ââç‰∏ÄÊ†∑Â∑•‰Ωú„ÄÇÈÇ£ÈáåÂèëÁîü‰∫Ü‰ªÄ‰πàÔºü‰∏∫‰ªÄ‰πàthisÂú®the_questionÂÜÖÈÉ®‰∏éBigComputerÂÜÖÈÉ®ÁöÑÊÑè‰πâ‰∏ç‰∏ÄÊ†∑ÔºüÁÆÄÂçïÊù•ËØ¥ÔºåÊàë‰ª¨ÈÄöËøánew ËøõÂÖ•‰∫ÜBigComputerÔºåÊâÄ‰ª•thisË°®Á§∫‚ÄùÊñ∞ÂØπË±°‚Äù„ÄÇÂè¶‰∏ÄÊñπÈù¢ÔºåÊàë‰ª¨ÈÄöËøádeep_thoughtËøõÂÖ•‰∫Üthe_questionÔºåÊâÄ‰ª•ÂΩìÊàë‰ª¨ÊâßË°å‰∫ÜÈÇ£‰∏™ÊñπÊ≥ïÔºåthisÊÑèÂë≥ÁùÄ‚Äùdeep_thoughtÊåáÂêëÁöÑ‰ªª‰ΩïÂÄº‚Äù„ÄÇthis‰∏çÂÉèÂÖ∂‰ªñÂèòÈáè‰∏ÄÊ†∑Ôºå‰ªé‰ΩúÁî®ÂüüÈìæ‰∏≠ËØªÂèñÔºåËÄåÊòØÂú®‰∏ä‰∏ãÊñáÁöÑÂü∫Á°Ä‰∏äÈáçÁΩÆ„ÄÇ Ë∞ÉÁî®ÊôÆÈÄöÂáΩÊï∞ Â¶ÇÊûúÊàë‰ª¨Âè™ÊòØË∞ÉÁî®‰∏Ä‰∏™ÊôÆÈÄöÁöÑÊó•Â∏∏ÁöÑÊ≤°ÊúâÂÖ∂‰ªñËä±Ê†∑ÁöÑÂáΩÊï∞Âë¢ÔºüÂú®ËøôÁßçÂú∫ÊôØ‰∏≠thisÂèàÂ¶Ç‰ΩïÊåáÂêëÔºü 1234function test_this(){ return this;}var i_wonder_what_this_is = test_this(); Âú®ËøôÁßçÊÉÖÂÜµ‰∏ãÔºåÊàë‰ª¨Ê≤°ÊúâÊèê‰æõÊñ∞ÁöÑ‰∏ä‰∏ãÊñáÔºå‰πüÊ≤°ÊúâÁªôÂá∫‰∏Ä‰∏™ËÉåÊôØÂΩ¢ÂºèÁöÑ‰∏ä‰∏ãÊñáÊù•ÊçéÂ∏¶„ÄÇÂú®ËøôÈáåÔºåthisÂèØ‰ª•ÂºïÁî®ÊúÄÂÖ®Â±ÄÁöÑ‰∏úË•øÔºöÂØπ‰∫éÁΩëÈ°µÔºåÂ∞±ÊòØwindowÂØπË±°„ÄÇ ‰∫ã‰ª∂Â§ÑÁêÜÂô®ÔºàEvent HandlerÔºâÂØπ‰∫éÊ≠£Â∏∏ÂáΩÊï∞Ë∞ÉÁî®ÁöÑÊõ¥Â§çÊùÇÁöÑËΩ¨Êç¢ÔºåÂÅáËÆæÊàë‰ª¨Ê≠£Âú®‰ΩøÁî®ÂáΩÊï∞Êù•Â§ÑÁêÜonclick‰∫ã‰ª∂„ÄÇÂΩì‰∫ã‰ª∂Âá∫ÂèëÊàë‰ª¨ÁöÑÂáΩÊï∞ÊâßË°åÊó∂ÔºåthisÊåáÂêëÂì™ÈáåÂë¢Ôºü‰∏çÂπ∏ÁöÑÊòØÔºåËøô‰∏™ÈóÆÈ¢òÊ≤°ÊúâÁÆÄÂçïÁöÑÁ≠îÊ°à„ÄÇÂ¶ÇÊûúÊàë‰ª¨ÂÜÖËÅîÂú∞ÂÜô‰∏Ä‰∏™‰∫ã‰ª∂Â§ÑÁêÜÂáΩÊï∞ÔºåthisÊåáÂêëÂÖ®Â±ÄÁöÑwindowÂØπË±°Ôºö12345function click_handler(){ alert(this); // alerts the window object}// ...// <button id="thebutton" onclick="click_handler()">Click me!</button> ÁÑ∂ËÄåÔºåÂΩìÊàë‰ª¨ÈÄöËøáJSÊù•Ê∑ªÂä†‰∏Ä‰∏™‰∫ã‰ª∂Â§ÑÁêÜÂáΩÊï∞ÔºåthisÂ∞±ÊåáÂêë‰∫ÜÁîüÊàê‰∫ã‰ª∂ÁöÑDOMÂÖÉÁ¥†„ÄÇ123456789function click_handler() { alert(this); // alerts the button DOM node }function addhandler() { document.getElementById(‚Äòthebutton‚Äô).onclick = click_handler; }window.onload = addhandler; ÈöæÈ¢òËÆ©Êàë‰ª¨Âú®ÊúÄÂêé‰∏Ä‰∏™‰æãÂ≠ê‰∏≠ËøêË°å‰∏Ä‰ºöÂÑø„ÄÇÂ¶ÇÊûú‰∏çÊòØËøêË°åclick_handlerÔºåÊàë‰ª¨ÊØèÊ¨°ÁÇπÂáªÊåâÈíÆÊó∂ÈÉΩÊÉ≥‚ÄùÈóÆdeep_thought‰∏Ä‰∏™question‚ÄùÊÄé‰πàÂäûÔºü‰ª£Á†ÅÁúãËµ∑Êù•ÈùûÂ∏∏ÁÆÄÂçï:1234567891011121314function BigComputer(answer) { this.the_answer = answer; this.ask_question = function () { alert(this.the_answer); }}function addhandler() { var deep_thought = new BigComputer(42), the_button = document.getElementById(‚Äôthebutton‚Äò); the_button.onclick = deep_thought.ask_question;}window.onload = addhandler; ÂæàÂÆåÁæéÔºåÂØπÂêßÔºüÊàë‰ª¨ÁÇπÂáª‰∫ÜÊåâÈíÆÔºådeep_thought.ask_questionË¢´ÊâßË°å‰∫ÜÔºåÁÑ∂ÂêéÊàë‰ª¨ÂæóÂà∞‚Äù42‚Äù„ÄÇÈÇ£‰πà‰∏∫‰ªÄ‰πàÊµèËßàÂô®Âç¥ÁªôÊàë‰ª¨ËøîÂõû‰∫Ü undefinedÔºüÊàë‰ª¨ÈÇ£ÈáåÈîô‰∫ÜÔºü ÈóÆÈ¢òÂæàÁÆÄÂçïÔºöÊàë‰ª¨‰º†ÈÄí‰∫ÜÂØπask_questionÊñπÊ≥ïÁöÑÂºïÁî®ÔºåÂΩì‰Ωú‰∏∫‰∫ã‰ª∂Â§ÑÁêÜÁ®ãÂ∫èÊâßË°åÊó∂ÔºåËØ•ÊñπÊ≥ïÂú®‰∏é‰Ωú‰∏∫ÂØπË±°ÊñπÊ≥ïÊâßË°åÊó∂‰∏çÂêåÁöÑ‰∏ä‰∏ãÊñá‰∏≠ÊâßË°å„ÄÇÁÆÄÁü≠Êù•ËØ¥Ôºåask_question‰∏≠ÁöÑ this ÂÖ≥ÈîÆÂ≠óÔºåÊåáÂêë‰∫ÜÁîüÊàê‰∫ã‰ª∂ÁöÑDOMÂÖÉÁ¥†ÔºåËÄå‰∏çÊòØBigComputerÂØπË±°„ÄÇËøô‰∏™DOMÂÖÉÁ¥†Ê≤°Êúâthe_answerÂ±ûÊÄßÔºåÂõ†Ê≠§Êàë‰ª¨Â∞ÜËøîÂõûundefinedÔºåËÄå‰∏çÊòØ‚Äú42‚Äù„ÄÇsetTimeout Ë°®Áé∞Âá∫Á±ª‰ººÁöÑË°å‰∏∫ÔºåÂª∂ËøüÂáΩÊï∞ÁöÑÊâßË°åÔºåÂêåÊó∂Â∞ÜÂÖ∂ÁßªÂä®Âà∞‰∫ÜÂÖ®Â±Ä‰∏ä‰∏ãÊñá‰∏≠„ÄÇ Ëøô‰∏™ÈóÆÈ¢òÈÅçÂ∏ÉÂú®Êàë‰ª¨ÁöÑÁ®ãÂ∫è‰∏≠ÔºåÂ¶ÇÊûúÊ≤°Êúâ‰ªîÁªÜË∑üË∏™Á®ãÂ∫èÊâÄÊúâËßíËêΩÁöÑÊÉÖÂÜµÔºåË∞ÉËØïÊòØ‰∏Ä‰∏™ÈùûÂ∏∏Âõ∞ÈöæÁöÑÈóÆÈ¢òÔºåÁâπÂà´ÊòØÂ¶ÇÊûú‰Ω†ÁöÑÂØπË±°ÂÖ∑ÊúâDOMÂÖÉÁ¥†‰∏äÂ≠òÂú®ÁöÑÂ±ûÊÄßÊàñËÄÖwindowÂØπË±°„ÄÇ ‰ΩøÁî®.apply() Âíå .call()‰øÆÊîπ‰∏ä‰∏ãÊñáÊàë‰ª¨ÂæàÊÉ≥Âú®ÁÇπÂáªÊåâÈíÆÁöÑÊó∂ÂÄôÂêëdeep_thoughtÊèê‰∏Ä‰∏™ÈóÆÈ¢òÔºåÂπ∂‰∏îÊõ¥‰∏ÄËà¨Âú∞ËØ¥ÔºåÊàë‰ª¨Â∏åÊúõËÉΩÂ§üÂú®ÂìçÂ∫î‰∫ã‰ª∂ÂíåsetTimeoutË∞ÉÁî®‰πãÁ±ªÁöÑ‰∫ãÊÉÖÊó∂Âú®ÂÖ∂Êú¨Âú∞‰∏ä‰∏ãÊñá‰∏≠Ë∞ÉÁî®ÂØπË±°ÊñπÊ≥ï„ÄÇ‰∏§‰∏™È≤ú‰∏∫‰∫∫Áü•ÁöÑJavaScriptÊñπÊ≥ïÔºåapply()Âíåcall()ÔºåÈÄöËøáÂÖÅËÆ∏Êàë‰ª¨Âú®ÊâßË°åÂáΩÊï∞Ë∞ÉÁî®Êó∂ÊâãÂä®Ë¶ÜÁõñthisÁöÑÂÄºÔºåÊù•Èó¥Êé•ÂêØÁî®Ëøô‰∏™ÂäüËÉΩ„ÄÇÊàë‰ª¨ÂÖàÊù•Áúãcall:12345678910111213var first_object = { num: 42 }; entry.content: LeetCode JavaScript (1): Two Sum Áõ¥ËææÈìæÊé•Ôºöhttps://leetcode.com/problems/two-sum/ ÈóÆÈ¢òGiven an array of integers, return indices of the two numbers such that they add up to a specific target. You may assume that each input would have exactly one solution, and you may not use the same element twice. entry.content: ‰πîÂ∏ÉÊñØÂú®ÊñØÂù¶Á¶èÂ§ßÂ≠¶ÁöÑÊºîËÆ≤„ÄäSpeech in Stanford„Äã ‰πîÂ∏ÉÊñØÊòØÊàëÁöÑÂÅ∂ÂÉè„ÄÇÁ∫µÁÑ∂‰ªñÊúâÂæàÂ§öÁº∫ÁÇπÔºåÊúâÁöÑÁº∫ÁÇπËÆ©‰∏ñ‰∫∫Êó†Ê≥ïÊé•ÂèóÔºå‰ªñ‰ªçÁÑ∂ÊòØÊàëÁöÑÂÅ∂ÂÉè„ÄÇ ËøôÁØáÊºîËÆ≤ÊòØÂú®2005Âπ¥ÊñØÂù¶Á¶èÂ§ßÂ≠¶ÁöÑÊØï‰∏öÂÖ∏Á§º‰∏äÂèëË°®ÁöÑÔºå‰πîÂ∏ÉÊñØÂΩìÊó∂ÊòØËãπÊûúÂÖ¨Âè∏ÁöÑCEOÔºåÂÖº‰ªªÁöÆÂÖãÊñØÂä®ÁîªÂ∑•‰ΩúÂÆ§ÁöÑCEO„ÄÇ‰πîÂ∏ÉÊñØ(1955-2011)ÔºåÊºîËÆ≤Êó∂Âπ¥50Â≤ÅÔºåÂàöÂàöÁªèÂéÜËÉ∞ËÖ∫ÁôåÁöÑÊ≤ªÁñóÂπ∂‰∏î‚ÄùÊöÇÊó∂‚ÄùÁóäÊÑàÔºå‰ªñÁî®Ëá™Â∑±ÁöÑ‰∫∫ÁîüÁªèÂéÜÂêëÂΩìÊó∂ÁöÑÊñØÂù¶Á¶èÊØï‰∏öÁîüÔºå‰ª•ÂèäÂÖ®‰∏ñÁïåÁöÑËßÇ‰ºóÔºåË°®Ëææ‰∫ÜËá™Â∑±ÂØπ‰∫∫ÁîüÂùöÂÆöÁöÑ‰ø°Âøµ„ÄÇ ‰∏≠ÂøÉËßÇÁÇπ Love what you do, believe it is great work. Keep looking for things you love, don‚Äôt settle. Your time is limited, don‚Äôt waste it living someone else‚Äôs life. Don‚Äôt let the noise of others‚Äô opinions drown out your inner voice. Have the courage to follow your heart and intuition. Stay Hungry. Stay Foolish. Time point of the speechThis is a prepared text of the Commencement address delivered by Steve Jobs, CEO of Apple Computer and of Pixar Animation Studios, on June 12, 2005. The original text of the speechI am honored to be with you today at your commencement from one of the finest universities in the world.I never graduated from college.Truth be told, this is the closest i‚Äôve ever gotten to a college graduation.Today I want to tell you three stories from my life.That‚Äôs it. No big deal. Just three stories. The first story is about connecting the dots. I dropped out of Reed College after the first 6 months, but then stayed around as a drop-in for another 18 months or so before I really quit. So why did I drop out? It started before I was born.My biological mother was a young, unwed college graduate student, and she decided to put me up for adoption.She felt very strongly that I should be adopted by college graduates, so everything was all set for me to be adopted at birth by a lawyer and his wife.Except that when I popped out they decided at the last minute that they really wanted a girl.So my parents, who were on a waiting list, got a call in the middle of the night asking: ‚Äú We have an unexpected baby boy; do you want him?‚ÄùThey said: ‚ÄúOf course.‚ÄùMy biological mother later found out that my mother had never graduated from high school.She refused to sign the final adoption papers.She only relented a few months later when my parents promised that I would someday go to college. And 17 years later I did go to college. But I naively chose a college that was almost as expensive as Stanford, and all of my working-class parents‚Äô savings were being spent on my college tuition.After six months, I couldn‚Äôt see the value in it.I had no idea what I wanted to do with my life and no idea how college was going to help me figure it out.And here I was spending all of the money my parents had saved their entire life.So I decided to drop out and trust that it would all work out OK.It was pretty scary at the time, but looking back it was one of the best decisions I ever made.The minute I dropped out I could stop taking the required classes that didn‚Äôt interest me, and begin dropping in on the ones that looked interesting. It wasn‚Äôt all romantic.I didn‚Äôt have a dorm room, so I slept on the floor in friends‚Äô rooms, I returned Coke bottles for 5$ deposit to buy foods with, and I would walk the 7 miles across town every Sunday night to get one good meal a week at the Hare Krishna temple.I love it.And much of what I stumbled into by following my curiosity and intuition turned out be priceless laster on. ÊàëËøΩÈöèËá™Â∑±ÁöÑÂ•ΩÂ•áÂøÉÂíåÁõ¥ËßâÔºåÂÅ∂ÁÑ∂ÂèëÁé∞ÂÖ∂‰∏≠ÁöÑÂ§ßÈÉ®ÂàÜÂÜÖÂÆπÔºåÂêéÊù•ÈÉΩÂèòÂæóÊó†‰ª∑‰πãÂÆù„ÄÇ Let me give you one example:Reed College at that time offered perhaps the best calligraphy instruction in the country.Throughout the campus every poster, every label on every drawer, was beautifully hand calligraphed.Because i had dropped out and didn‚Äôt have to take the normal classes, I decided to take a calligraphy class to learn how to do this.I learned about serif and sans serif typefaces, about varying the amount of space between defferent letter combinations, about what makes great typography great.It was beautiful, historical, artistically subtle in a way that science can‚Äôt capture, and I found it fascinating. None of this had even a hope of any practical application in my life.But 10 years later, when we were designing the first Macintosh computer, it all came back to me.And we designed it all into the Mac.It was the first computer with beautiful typography.If I had never dropped in on that single course in college, the Mac would have never had multiple typefaces or proportionally spaced fonts.And since Windows just copied the Mac, it‚Äôs likely that no personal computer would have them.If I had never dropped out, I would have never dropped in on the calligraphy class, and personal computers might not have the wonderful typography that they do.Of course it was impossible to connect the dots looking forward when I was in college.But it was very, very clear looking backward 10 years later. Again, you can‚Äôt connect the dots looking forward; you can only connect them looking backward.So you have to trust that the dots will somehow connect in your future.You have to trust in something - your gut, destiny, life, karma, whatever.This approach has never let me down, and it has made all the difference inmy life. My second story is about love and loss. I was lucky ‚Äì I found what I loved to do early in life.Woz and I started Apple in my parents‚Äô garage when I was 20.We worked hard, and in 10 years Apple had grown from just the two of us in a garage into a $2 billion company with over 4,000 employees.We had just released our finest creation ‚Äì the Macintosh ‚Äì a year earlier, and i had just turned 30.And then I got fired.How can you get fired from a company you started?Well, as Apple grew we hired someone who I thought was very talented to run the company with me, and for the first year or so things went well.But then our visions of the future began to diverge and eventually we had a falling out.When we did, our Board of Directors sided with him.So at 30 I was out.And very publicly out.What had been the focus of my entire adult life was gone, and it was devastating. I really din‚Äôt know what to do for a few months.I felt that I had let the previous generation of entrepreneurs down ‚Äì that I had dropped the baton as it was being passed to me.I met with David Packard and Bod Noyce and tried to apologize for screwing up so badly.I was a very public failure, and I even thought about running away from the valley.But something slowly began to dawn on me ‚Äì I still loved what I did.The turn of events at Apple had not changed that one bit.I had been rejected, but I was still in love.And so I decided to start over. I didn‚Äôt see it then, but it turned out that getting fired from Apple was the best thing that could have ever happened to me.The heaviness of being successful was replaced by the lightness of being a beginner again, less sure about everything.It freed me to enter one of the most creative periods of my life. During the next five years, I started a company name NeXT, another company name Pixar, and fell in love with an amazing woman who would become my wife.Pixar went on to create the world‚Äôs first computer animated feature film, Toy Story, and is now the most successful animation studio in the world.In a remarkable turn of events, Apple bought NeXT, I returned to Apple, and the technology we developed at NeXT is at the heart of Apple‚Äôs current renaissance.And Laurene and I have a wonderful family together. I‚Äôm pretty sure none of this would have happened if I hadn‚Äôt been fired from Apple.It was awful tasting medicine, but I guess the patient needed it.Sometimes life hits you in the head with a brick.Don‚Äôt lose faith.I‚Äôm convinced that the only thine that kept me going was that I loved what I did.You‚Äôve got to find what you love.And that is as true for your work as it is for your lovers.Your work is going to fill a large part of your life, and the only way to be truly satisfied is to do what you believe is great work.And the only way to do great work is to love what you do.If you haven‚Äôt found it yet, keep looking.Don‚Äôt settle.As with all matters of the heart, you‚Äôll know when you find it.And, like any great relationship, it just gets better and better as the years roll on.So keep looking until you find it.Don‚Äôt settle. My third story is about death. When I was 17, I read a quote that went something like: ‚ÄúIf you live each day as if it was your last, somyday you‚Äôll most certainly be right.‚ÄùIt made an impression on me, and since then, for the past 33 years, I have looked in the mirror every morning and asked myself: ‚Äúif today were the last day of my life, would I want to do what I‚Äôm about to do today?‚ÄùAnd whenever the answer has been ‚ÄúNo‚Äù for too many days in a row, I know I need to change something. Remembering that I‚Äôll be dead soon is the most important tool I‚Äôve ever encountered to help m make the big choices in life.Because almost everything ‚Äì all external expectations, all pride, all fear of embarrassment or failure ‚Äì these thins just fall away in the face of death, leaving only what is truly important.Remembering that you are going to die is the best way I know to avoid the trap of thinking you have something to lose.You are already naked.There is no reason not to follow your heart. About a year ago I was diagnosed with cancer.I had a scan at 7:30 in the moning, and it clearly showed a tumor on my pancreas.I didn‚Äôt even know what a pancreas was.The doctors told me this was almost certainly a type of cancer that is incurable, and that I should expect to live no longer than three to six months.My doctor advised me to go home and get my affairs in order, which is doctor‚Äôs code for prepare to die.it means to try to tell your kids everything you thought you‚Äôd have the next 10 years to tell them in just a few months.It means to make sure everything is buttoned up so that it will be as easy as possible for your family.It means to say your goodbyes. I lived with that diagnosis all day.Later that evening I had a biopsy, where they stuck an endoscope down my throat, through my stomach and into my intestines, put a needle into my pancreas and got a few cells from the tumor.I was sedated, but my wife, who was there, told me that when they viewed the cells under a microscope the doctors started crying because it turned out to be a very rare form of pancreatic cancer that is curable with surgery.I had the surgery and I‚Äôm fine now. This was the closest I‚Äôve been to facing death, and I hope it‚Äôs the closest I get for a few more decades.Having lived through it, I can now say this to you with a bit more certainty that when death was a useful but purely intellectual concept: No one wants to die. Even people who want to go to heaven don‚Äôt want to die to get there. And yet death is the destination we all share. No one has ever escaped it. And that is as it should be, because Death is very likely the single best invention of Life. It is Life‚Äôs change agent. It clears out the old to make way for the new. Right now the new is you, but somyday not too long from now, you will gradually become the old and be cleared away. Sorry to be so dramatic, but it is quite true. Your time is limited, so don‚Äôt waste it living someone else‚Äôs life.Don‚Äôt be trapped by dogma ‚Äì which is living with the results of other people‚Äôs thinking.Don‚Äôt let the noise of others‚Äô opinions drown out your own inner voice.And most important, have the courage to follow your heart and intuition.They somehow already know what you truly want to become.Everything else is secondary. When I was young, there was an amazing publication called The Whole Earth Catalog, which was one of the bibles of my generation. It was created by a fellow named Stewart Brand not far from here in Menlo Park, and he brought it to life with his poetic touch. This was in the late 1960s, before personal computers and desktop publishing, so it was all made with typewriters, scissors and Polaroid cameras. It was sort of like Google in paperback form, 35 years before Google came along: It was idealistic, and overflowing with neat tools and great notions. Stewart and his team put out a final issue. It was the mid-1970s, and I was your age. On the back cover of their final issue was a photograph of an early morning country road, the kind you might find yourself hitchhiking on if you were so adventurous. Beneath it were the words:‚Äù Stay Hungry. Stay Foolish.‚Äù It was their farewell message as they signed off. Stay Hungry. Stay Foolish. And I have always wished that for myself. And now, as you graduate to begin anew, I wish that for you. Stay Hungry. Stay Foolish. Thank you all very much. } if(a>b){ return 1; } return 0;}str_arr.sort(compareStr);// ['apples', 'bananas', 'cherries'] 2.1 Êï∞Â≠óÊéíÂ∫è Â¶ÇÊûúcompareFunction(a, b)Â∞è‰∫é0ÔºåÈÇ£‰πàa‰ºöÊéíÂà∞b‰πãÂâçÔºõ Â¶ÇÊûúcompareFunction(a, b)Á≠â‰∫é0 , ÈÇ£‰πà‰ΩçÁΩÆ‰∏çÂèòÔºõ Â¶ÇÊûúcompareFunction(a, b)Â§ß‰∫é0ÔºåÈÇ£‰πàb‰ºöÊéíÂà∞a‰πãÂâçÔºõ12345678910111213141516function compareNumbers(a, b){ return a - b;}var numbers = [4, 2, 5, 1, 3];numbers.sort(function(a, b){ return a - b;});console.log(numbers);//‰πüÂèØ‰ª•ÂÜôÊàêÔºövar numbers = [4, 2, 5, 1, 3];numbers.sort((a, b) => a - b);console.log(numbers);//ËæìÂá∫Ôºö[1, 2, 3, 4, 5] 2.2 ÂØπË±°ÊåâÁÖßÊüê‰∏™Â±ûÊÄßÊéíÂ∫è1234567891011121314151617181920212223242526var items = [ { name: 'Edward', value: 21 }, { name: 'Sharpe', value: 37 }, { name: 'And', value: 45 }, { name: 'The', value: -12 }, { name: 'Magnetic' }, { name: 'Zeros', value: 37 }];//ÊåâvalueÂÄºÊéíÂ∫èitems.sort(function (a,b){ return (a,.value - b.value)});//ÊåânameÂÄºÊéíÂ∫èitems.sort(function(a, b){ var nameA = a.name.toUpperCase(); var nameB = b.name.toUpperCase(); if(nameA < nameB){ return -1; } if(nameA > nameB){ return 1; } return 0;}); ‰∏â„ÄÅÈ´òÁ∫ßÊìç‰ΩúÔºö‰ΩøÁî®Êò†Â∞ÑÊîπÂñÑÊéíÂ∫ècompareFunctionÂèØËÉΩÈúÄË¶ÅÂØπÂÖÉÁ¥†ÂÅöÂ§öÊ¨°Êò†Â∞Ñ‰ª•ÂÆûÁé∞ÊéíÂ∫èÔºåÂ∞§ÂÖ∂ÂΩìcompareFunctionËæÉ‰∏∫Â§çÊùÇÔºå‰∏îÂÖÉÁ¥†ËæÉÂ§öÁöÑÊó∂ÂÄôÔºåÊüê‰∫õcompareFunction ÂèØËÉΩ‰ºöÂØºËá¥ÂæàÈ´òÁöÑË¥üËΩΩ„ÄÇ‰ΩøÁî®mapËæÖÂä©ÊéíÂ∫èÂ∞Ü‰ºöÊòØ‰∏™Â•Ω‰∏ªÊÑè„ÄÇ Âü∫Êú¨ÊÄùÊÉ≥ÊòØÈ¶ñÂÖàÂ∞ÜÊï∞ÁªÑ‰∏≠ÁöÑÊØè‰∏™ÂÖÉÁ¥†ÊØîËæÉÁöÑÂÆûÈôÖÂÄºÂèñÂá∫Êù•ÔºåÊéíÂ∫èÂêéÂÜçÂ∞ÜÊï∞ÁªÑÊÅ¢Â§ç„ÄÇ 123456789101112131415161718// ÈúÄË¶ÅË¢´ÊéíÂ∫èÁöÑÊï∞ÁªÑvar list = ['Delta', 'alpha', 'CHARLIE', 'bravo'];// ÂØπÈúÄË¶ÅÊéíÂ∫èÁöÑÊï∞Â≠óÂíå‰ΩçÁΩÆÁöÑ‰∏¥Êó∂Â≠òÂÇ®, mapped‰∏∫‰∏¥Êó∂ÂÆπÂô®var mapped = list.map(function(el, i) { return { index: i, value: el.toLowerCase() };})// ÊåâÁÖßÂ§ö‰∏™ÂÄºÊéíÂ∫èÊï∞ÁªÑmapped.sort(function(a, b) { return +(a.value > b.value) || +(a.value === b.value) - 1;});// Ê†πÊçÆÁ¥¢ÂºïÂæóÂà∞ÊéíÂ∫èÁöÑÁªìÊûúvar result = mapped.map(function(el){ return list[el.index];});//result : ["alpha", "bravo", "CHARLIE", "Delta"]
